ids: {'description': 'Studies that use long‐running panel surveys that follow the same individuals over time; for example, the Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID), the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY), Understanding Society and similar nationally representative longitudinal surveys.', 'ids': ['13', '15', '35', '40', '102', '124', '127']}

{'description': 'Studies that rely on administrative records – such as tax filings, population registers, census microdata, or other government‐maintained databases – to measure parent and child outcomes.', 'ids': ['21', '24', '29', '30', '32', '83', '104', '109', '116', '210']}

{'description': 'Studies that use datasets designed for particular regions or topics – for instance, health and nutrition surveys, family panel studies from China or India (e.g. CHNS, CFPS, IHDS), Opportunity Insights data, or other specially collected datasets.', 'ids': ['17', '19', '22', '23', '41', '67', '69', '73']}

{'description': 'Studies that employ general cross‐sectional or repeated survey instruments (not full administrative panels) – such as the General Social Survey (GSS), European Social Survey (ESS), EU-SILC or similar national survey programs – to gauge intergenerational outcomes or subjective perceptions.', 'ids': ['34', '36', '38', '42', '43', '44', '46', '47', '52']}
{'description': 'Abstracts that did not explicitly mention any dataset used or provide any indication of data source.', 'ids': ['0', '1', '7', '8', '10', '11', '12']}

{'description': 'Abstracts whose data source did not clearly fall into any of the above categories (for example, papers that only describe theoretical models, qualitative experiments, or when the dataset is not the focus of the study).', 'ids': ['2', '3', '4', '5', '6', '14', '16']}
